defeat of Capt. "Andy" Knecht's
team at the hands of Delaware
College last Saturday by a score
of 5 to 3. Two circuit clouts by
"Dory" Collins, Delaware's portsider, were enough to give them
their winning margin of two runs.
Delaware scored single counters in the first, second and fifth
innings and put across a brace of
runs in the- seventh. - The Black
and Blue counted in the second
inning when Sharretts singled and
was worked around the paths.
After that Collins kept the Hopkins hits scattered until the ninth.
In this inning Rich singled and
"Andy" Knecht came through
with a home run, one of the longest hits ever witnessed on Fraser

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 31, 1922
HOPKINS DOWNS LEHIGH AT
LACROSSE

PHI PSI'S DEFEAT K. A.'S IN GOOD
BALL GAME

Continued ftom Page 1

Encouraged by their recent
close victory over Phi Gamma
Delta the baseball team of the
Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity humbled the Kappa Alpha's in a 4-3
score in the best game so far
played in the interfraternity
series. The game was marked by
its closeness throughout and few
errors were made on either side.
Both Jacobsen and Gundry, who
were seen on the mound, showed
fine form, the former allowing
only two hits, having the edge.
Homer and Macgill did the receiving and both took care of
their jobs in creditable fashion.
The fielding of Brent Wills, who
covered the left corner of the garden for the K. A.'s, was feature
of the game.
An accident, which occurred in
the fourth inning, somewhat
marred the victory. Hammond,
who was covering the initial sack
for the winners,•in an attempt to
score what proved to be the winning run, was blocked by Macgill
and the impact broke the former's
left arm. He was given first aid
by "Doc" Engel and then taken
to a hospital.
The runs scored were scattered
throughout the game. Each collected a run in the first. The winners gathered their others in the
second, fourth and sixth, while
the losers tallied in the fourth and
sixth. In the final inning it looked
as if the game would end in a tie,
The K. A.'s having two men on
base with none down. Jacobsen,
however, pulled himself together
and the next three men were
quickly eliminated. The lineup:

seen this year. Jenks Cromwell,

It has not yet been decided just
what action the officials of the
league will take with regard to the
tie now existing between Hopkins
and Lehigh, and Penn resulting
from Penn's victory over Hopkins. Several years ago when the
season ended in a tie the championship was awarded to Lehigh
because she had been champion
the previous year. On that occasion, however, Hopkins did not
defeat Lehigh. Whether Hopkins
victory over the claimants will
entitle them to the Southern title
this year or whether Lehigh will
retain it by virtue of having held
it last year is a question that will
be decided by league officials in
time to play off the national championship game. with -Syracuse at

FRESHMAN CLASS HOLDS LAST
MEETING

Friday afternoon was the last
time that the Class of '25 met as
Freshmen. The entire time of the
meeting was devoted to a report
on the financial condition of the
class. Treasurer "Bill" Norris
announced that $2 would be taken
from the caution fee of those students who had not paid the class
dues. He also announced that an
effort was being made to procure
a few more leather-bound programs to be given as souvenirs to
those who did not receive any at
the banquet.
Following these announcements, Norris read a detailed ac•
count of the dues collected and
the necessary expenditures.
After the meeting the class
gave a Hullabaloo for '25.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 31, 1922
HOPKINS DOWNS LEHIGH AT
LACROSSE

PHI PSI'S DEFEAT K. A.'S IN GOOD
BALL GAME

Continued ftom Page 1

Encouraged by their recent
close victory over Phi Gamma
Delta the baseball team of the
Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity humbled the Kappa Alpha's in a 4-3
score in the best game so far
played in the interfraternity
series. The game was marked by
its closeness throughout and few
errors were made on either side.
Both Jacobsen and Gundry, who
were seen on the mound, showed
fine form, the former allowing
only two hits, having the edge.
Homer and Macgill did the receiving and both took care of
their jobs in creditable fashion.
The fielding of Brent Wills, who
covered the left corner of the garden for the K. A.'s, was feature
of the game.
An accident, which occurred in
the fourth inning, somewhat
marred the victory. Hammond,
who was covering the initial sack
for the winners,•in an attempt to
score what proved to be the winning run, was blocked by Macgill
and the impact broke the former's
left arm. He was given first aid
by "Doc" Engel and then taken
to a hospital.
The runs scored were scattered
throughout the game. Each collected a run in the first. The winners gathered their others in the
second, fourth and sixth, while
the losers tallied in the fourth and
sixth. In the final inning it looked
as if the game would end in a tie,
The K. A.'s having two men on
base with none down. Jacobsen,
however, pulled himself together
and the next three men were
quickly eliminated. The lineup:

seen this year. Jenks Cromwell,
playing for Capt. Zoller, who is
out with a bad knee, and Huey at
attack also showed up well.
It has not yet been decided just
what action the officials of the
league will take with regard to the
tie now existing between Hopkins
and Lehigh, and Penn resulting
from Penn's victory over Hopkins. Several years ago when the
season ended in a tie the championship was awarded to Lehigh
because she had been champion
the previous year. On that occasion, however, Hopkins did not
defeat Lehigh. Whether Hopkins
victory over the claimants will
entitle them to the Southern title
this year or whether Lehigh will
retain it by virtue of having held
it last year is a question that will
be decided by league officials in
time to play off the national championship game. with -Syracuse at
either Bethlehem or Baltimore
next Saturday.

game follows:

FRESHMAN CLASS HOLDS LAST
MEETING

Friday afternoon was the last
time that the Class of '25 met as
Freshmen. The entire time of the
meeting was devoted to a report
on the financial condition of the
class. Treasurer "Bill" Norris
announced that $2 would be taken
from the caution fee of those students who had not paid the class
dues. He also announced that an
effort was being made to procure
a few more leather-bound programs to be given as souvenirs to
those who did not receive any at
the banquet.
Following these announcements, Norris read a detailed ac•
count of the dues collected and
the necessary expenditures.
After the meeting the class
gave a Hullabaloo for '25.
